title: Before 1 January 2018, will two of the three major credit rating agencies adjust the long-term issuer credit rating of Venezuela or the PDVSA to indicate default?
preds: Back to 0, suspect the outcome will be 3 agencies have indicated default (not 2) before Jan.1.
Might have it right this time.

It is true that downrating doesn't automatically follow a declared default, but it's also true that the wording of this Q, "to indicate default," may not require a default to have occurred at all.  It doesn't say "as a result of a default," so if the ratings are hurt because of heightened risk of default, that might count:  If I put up a sign that says "Moose Crossing"--or depending on where you live, "Elephant Crossing" or "Camel Crossing"--no moose or moose equivalent need actually be crossing just then, or to have crossed lately; the sign is still meant to "indicate" the danger of a nasty collision.

So what might the scorers of this question decide? Did they default, or didn't they? In the past, major credit rating agencies have walked back default ratings.  So what happens if only a temporary default was declared?

The International Swaps and Derivatives Association (ISDA) committee’s unanimous decision that the delays constitute a “credit event” triggers limited payouts on credit default swaps (CDS).

"A Venezuelan state enterprise allegedly defaulted this week, after months of speculation the government in Caracas could struggle to make debt repayments.
State-owned energy utility Corpoelec has allegedly defaulted on a bond interest payment worth more than US$650 million, according to Reuters. The news agency cited a statement from the bond’s trustee, Wilmington Trust.
“The issuer’s failure to pay interest on the notes when due on October 10, 2017 constitutes a default under the indenture,” Wilmington reportedly stated in notice posted on the Luxembourg stock exchange.
Wilmington didn’t provide further details, while Corpoelec has denied it has defaulted. The company stated it made the payment on November 8, a day before it was due.
President Nicolas Maduro had previously announced plans to restructure some of his government’s debt, with talks with investors set to take place on Monday.
If confirmed, the default won’t automatically trigger further defaults, and according to experts any lawsuit stemming from the payment failure would likely be directed at Corpoelec – not the government itself.
Maduro has long dismissed speculation his government could itself be facing default.
Venezuela’s government and state enterprises like PDVSA collectively owe around US$143 billion in foreign debt, according to financial thinktank Torino Capital. PDVSA alone has around US1.6 billion in debt payments due by the end of the year, and another US$9 billion on bond servicing set to fall in 2018."

CHICAGO -- Fitch Ratings has downgraded Petroleos de Venezuela S.A.'s (PDVSA) Long-Term Foreign Currency Issuer Default Rating (IDR) to 'C' from 'CC' and affirmed the company's Local Currency IDR at 'CC' and National scale at 'CCC(ven)'. The rating action affects all of PDVSA's international senior unsecured and secured debt issuances, which have been downgraded to 'C'/'RR4' from 'CC'/'RR4'. A full list of rating actions follows at the end of this rating action commentary.

State-owned Petroleos de Venezuela SA, keeper of the world’s largest oil reserves, has seen output drop to a 14-year low, beset by the country’s economic collapse, a global plunge in crude prices and U.S. sanctions. As American refineries, once PDVSA’s top customers, have bought less, China and Russia have stepped in. The two countries have loaned more than USD60 billion to boost production there, prepaying for more than a billion barrels.
Fitch Ratings said Venezuela's debt default is probable late Friday, and it downgraded the country's long-term foreign currency debt rating deeper into distressed territory.

Pro
1) Maduro announced refinancing and restructuring
2) There were delays
3) US sanctions (prohibition of new debts and restrictions with old debts)
4) Possibility of Maduro's regime change
Con
1) Payments in past years were paid and this year they paid debts, despite the much lower price of oil
2) Venezuela has the largest oil reserves. China and Russia are interested in their crude oil inventory (strategy in long period of time)
3) Russia does not give up halfway
4) Maduro in any case need to pay debts (or a change Maduro)
5) After Thursday's payment, Venezuela has no foreign bond maturities until the second half of 2018

"The risk is that OPEC's rediscovered optimism encourages members to pursue ever-higher prices again, justifying each increase as a move toward that magical "fair price". It's starting to happen already. At the end of October, Qatar's oil minister said prices were moving in the "right direction" toward fair levels, even as Brent passed $60.  "might have taken longer than some market players expected, but Venezuela finally announced this week it will seek to restructure its global debt; one estimate puts the overseas debt owed by the government and state entities at about $143 billion, including some $52 billion in bonds. The Latin American country had long struggled to avoid default. The local economist who had urged President Nicolas Maduro to default is now concerned that any restructuring will be very painful, and may do little to help the country as a whole. The government did say that state-run oil company PDVSA was making payments that fell due late October, which may relieve some traders. The saga left Mark Mobius happy he had stayed away ever since Hugo Chavez came to power in 1999."

3) 2% Is there some advantage to Russia of default that I'm not weighing properly (like uncertainty in the oil market causing oil prices to rise); or 
4) 1% will Maduro and Russia be unable to get an agreement done despite both having a desire to do so?

The higher price of oil should ideally give some added breathing space to the government.

I don't normally use any "news" from Zerohedge because they may well be a Russian propaganda front. However, in this case, with Russia being Maduro's ally, I expect Zero Hedge to carry Putin's water, er, oil. Currently, Zero Hedge is continuing to assert that that there is no default looming before the forecast horizon.  In addition, financial news sites have been carrying headlines warning of default since practically forever, so I'm seeing little boy who cried wolf syndrome. Indeed, the base rate for Venezuela default is essentially zero, with the last default in 1982, 35 years ago. Therefore the base rate of one in 35 years turns into ~0.6% between now and the forecast horizon. Therefore, I'm holding at zero probability. (And if I blow it, IMHO, better to be hanged for a sheep as a lamb.)

S&P cuts Venezuela debt ratings, sees risk of default (AFP)
S&P Global Ratings said today it has lowered Venezuela's sovereign debt ratings, warning of the risk of default as economic conditions in the oil-rich country worsen and political tensions rise. S&P said it had lowered "long-term foreign and local currency sovereign credit ratings on the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela to 'CCC-' from 'CCC.'" The downgrade "reflects continued deterioration in economic conditions, rising political tensions, including within the Chavista government base, and the government's worsening liquidity position. "Economic policy continues to be erratic, in a context of very high inflation; severe fiscal, monetary, and exchange-rate rigidities; and draconian controls on imports."
Venezuela Cut Deeper into Junk by S&P

Increasing probability of default due to significant decrease in oil production in April 2017 from 2,235K barrels per day in March to 2,194 barrels per day in April. According to OPEC, oil accounts for 95% of total exports. As the rest of the economy collapses, the debt burden will become greater.

The implied probability of nonpayment in the next 12 months surged to 56 percent in March from 40 percent in February, according to credit-default swaps data compiled by Bloomberg. That’s the biggest jump in the perceived risk of a short-term default since November, when cash-strapped Petroleos de Venezuela SA missed coupon payments due on its bonds and had to use a 30-day grace period as the opposition called for a national strike and protests
If PDVSA manages to pay its debt on April 12 [which they did], the company and Venezuela will get some breathing room before facing payments of $3.5 billion in October and November. The odds of a credit event over the next five years is 92 percent, according to CDS data.

Moody's: Caa3 with a negative outlook. Caa3 means a default imminent with little prospect for recovery and that they are trending downward

Fitch: CCC and no outlook. Same meaning as S&P but without the negative outlook

Scary as the situation might be in Venezuela, PDVSA is so far honoring its debts with its suppliers; it is the general population that is suffering. Credit ratings value the risk of default towards creditors, not whether the population is starving for lack of basic supplies, and Venezuela is still one of the richest countries in terms of oil reserves, they just do not know to administer it. Credit rating of PDVSA is directly linked to the rating of the country, and once the country is downgraded a downgrade for PDVSA will be automatic. 
In case Maduro will come down, no one would like to bury the hope for a change by a downgrade (except Putin and the Arabian oil producers, maybe), and given the history with Venezuela, which lingers since a couple of years, it does not look like credit rating will be used to force Maduro out of office.

Default is common outcome historically in socialist central and south American countries, especially where prices and/or wages are fixed.  The government has demonstrated a commitment to service its debt, but Venezuela's ability to do so going forward is highly questionable as it faces extreme levels of civil unrest.  Debt denominated in other nation's currency will be increasingly difficult to pay.  Falling oil prices and lack of meaningful economic activity will generate large deficits and drive hyperinflation. IMF could bail the country out, but Maduro has lost respect of many international leaders and institutions.

Venezuela is a failed state. While it may have temporarily funded this round of payments the country is in dire straits on many economic and social fronts.  Maduro may survive through 2017, however, how will he juggle the demands of a starving populace, and a "one legged" economy dependent on the price of oil?  China and Russia could continue their investment in Venezuela, however I give that only a 15% chance with regime change in the winds.
